lg.l: After [she with] the appearance of being adorned [as] a woman
The perfect feet of the blessed first lady, saying ‘This woman
Cannot bear the summer’s harsh rays, [her] little feet
Are not accustomed to the pebbles in the hot forest.
[There], even the hunting, strong bear will not dig out curved anthills.
Even the brightly striped tiger will not confront the herd of animals/deer.
The snake, the Cūr spirit and the crocodile that searches for prey
Will not create distress to those who are dependent [on this path],
Saying, this is the land that is guarded by the southern one
With a straight sceptre. As for its fame that has gone everywhere,
It is big! There is no danger to cross the long path
In the middle of the night, with a lamp that is the moonlight,
That protects many lives even more than the brightness of midday.’
[Thus], abiding by the principles that were agreed upon
By the respected one (Kavunti), [They] being like the clans
[Under] a king [with] a cruel sceptre, to those who stayed,
Looking out [for] the [right] occasion [of departing of]
The setting rays [of the sun], a young man [at] the base
Of the family of the southern one [i.e., the Pāṇṭiya king]
Appearing, having spread milky rays along with an army
Of many stars; After the lady of the earth became still,
Having sighed in distress, saying, ‘A string of star[-like pearls] and
A mixture of sandal paste being left out, not joining
A cool, flower garland of lilies with pollen
Being left out, not joining [your] flower[-like] tresses
[To which] buds [should be] joined, Many flowering
short shoots, along with fresh sprouts, being left out,
Not joining, [your] body [like] a red/perfect sprout,
Would you [really] wish for the moon of the summer season
- As it showers upon girls [its] milky, white rays -
Along with the southern wind that was united to the tongues
Of poets, having risen in the Mayala mountains, growing in Maturai,
[Kōvalaṉ] looking at the lady [Kaṇṇaki] who bore the difficult path,
Saying, ’The [tiger with] curved stripes will roam about. The owl
Will call out. The bear which produces thunderous noise will not acquiesce.
Walk on!’ showing [her] red/beautiful hands [with] bracelets [and] bangles]
To [his] shoulders, [both of them] listening to the words of Dharma
[From her with] the faultless traditional knowledge/śruti which had forsaken
Words of bravery [= war], [thus] crossing the difficult path over there,
In the forest with [burned] blackened bamboo in which the summer was enthroned,
As the forest fowl announced the arrival of the rays [of the sun],
Having reached the abode in which those with twisted threads on the chest resided,
Of the deviation from the Vedic treatises [because of] the principles of uttering/promoting
The Vari dances/songs, [Kōvalaṉ] making stay inside one room of faultless excellence
[His] lover (Kaṇṇaki) along with the lady of the great penance,
Having left the [area with] a fence in which thorns were placed, over there,
Along one long path, he bathed in the water. Becoming perturbed,
Being one who sighed like fire bellows blowing [into] a fireplace
For [i.e, because of] the journey into the forest with his lady love,
Kaucikaṉ did not recognise/perceive [Kōvalaṉ as his] form roamed about
Because of [Kōvalaṉ] having loneliness on the inside,
Because of a confusion/disturbance of [his] vision.
Saying, ‘Oh Mātavi [creeper], [just] like Mātavi with long eyes [like] big blossoms
Who reached [a state of] cruel misery, as Kōvalaṉ separated [from her],
It seems you [too] suffered as soon as the flowers were removed
For [= because of] the summer [season], powerful in coming’,
Reaching an arbour of the Kurukatti tree with green leaves,
Saying, ‘What is this speech you have spoken here?’,
Saying, ‘I [now] saw [Kōvalaṉ], I am without bad feelings [= anxiety].’
Going [and] reaching [ Kōvalaṉ], Kōcikamāṇi would [now] narrate with [good] principles:
‘Mātavi having heard [from] the mouth of Vacantamālai [of]
The resemblance of the great hero with great treasures [Kōvalaṉ’s father] and
The great heroine of the big house to a snake that had lost [its] jewel,
The descending of the kinsfolk that had crowded [in Pukār] into a sea of misery
Like bodies that had lost [their] pleasant lives [= souls], saying ‘bring him back!,’
The departure of men [under] command going everywhere searching for Kōvalaṉ,
The confusion of the ancient town [with] a great name (Pukār) like Ayodhyā
From which the rare power [Rāma] had separated, having reached
The difficult forest, saying ‘Besides the command of the great man [= my father],
Statehood/kingly status is a negligble matter’,
The falling in the bedroom [on to] a bed suitable for lying down of
Her with a pallid body experiencing the pain of [this] affliction,
There on the middle floor of a storied house with [many] floors,
Hearing the distress of she with misery that brings [one] down,
The staying elsewhere of her, having reached [a state of] depressive misery,
She who had great misery saying, ‘I have worshipped your paired feet.
May you remove the misery that comes [to me]’,
Saying ‘Please show [this letter] to he who is the apple of my eye [Kōvalaṉ]’,
And,the entrusting by Mātavi of the palm-leaf bundle with a seal/estampage,
[Kaucikaṉ] taking the palm-leaf that was given [to him],
Being by the side of the path, narrating in a flawless manner
About all the lands that he who performed [with] with of fire [Kaucikaṉ] had gone [in vain],
As [Kōvalaṉ] amassed from [Kaucikaṉ;s] flower-hands the palm-leaves of the lady Mātavi
With a mind of loss, [that] woman of great sorrow [who was]
The lady [like] a flower-creeper, [with] twisted tresses [on which] buds open;
Because the impression of the seal showed [him], having revealed
The fragrance of oil [in her] tightly curled tresses
That spoke of [their] time of living together,
[His] hand could not submit to letting go [of it].
Having opened up the note, he will [now] know:
‘I fell to [your] feet, in front of you, oh eminent one.’
It is necessary to take to heart [my/these] unpractised/unembellished words.
[They], not knowing of my error for [your] departure
In the middle of the night, with the lady of a birth [from] a [good] clan,
Having realised the musical words that she had written, saying,
‘It is necessary to remove [my] desolate heart.
Praise be to you who is are eminent [as] a faultless sight!’
[Kōvalaṉ then] saying, ‘She is one who is without fault’,
Leaving [his state of] faintness, saying ‘[it is] my fault]’,
[Thus] realising [the meaning of] that which had reached [him],
Saying, ‘The narration of the matter, [in] this bundle [of manuscripts] possessing fragrant pastes
Being elegant (= appropriate), is acceptable to my father [= him who birthed me].
I worship the blossom-feet of my faultless parents.
Kaucikamāṇi, show [this letter to them].’ [thus] giving [the letter],
Gather [with them], for the removal of [their] distress,
That has come together with their good home/hearts!’,
Having reached her of Dharma (Kavunti) of faultless principles,
Who was with [his] faultless wife, joining closely
With bards who sang on the beauty of Antari (her of the space)
Of the principles of the nature of dancing,
Having forced into contact the capstan/bridge [to] the strings with the hand,
Of the Ceṅkōṭṭu type of lute with was made [for] the Centiṟam melody,
Joining [those strings] in a way [of being] grippedBecause of the possession of frets (?),
Tying, as Uḻai note being the beginning [and] Kaikkiḷai being the end,
[Kōvalaṉ] listening, so that it becomes befitting (= that it is musically correct),
To the constituents of Ācaṉ [type of melody?]
Of the song’s rhythm [on] the girl on a leaping stag
In the place of three types that occurd in three ways,
Mingling [into] the rhythm of the song
[Kaṇṇaki] saying, ‘Please tell [me] the [number of] Kāvatams [to] Kūṭal’,
[Kōvalaṉ] saying, ‘Mixing pastes of eaglewood, fragrant, beautiful vermillion, a musk-paste,
Beautiful powders, pastes of civet cat musk, a divine [mixture] fragrant with fragrance,
[Into] a sweet, tender, rich thick paste, joining [into] a wreath on which buds expand
[On] a flower-bed Mātavi jasmines, home-grown Mullai jasmines with
A garland of waterlilies with pollen [and] Campaka, the smoke from cooking fires,
The smoke [from] dumplings of pancake sellers that don’t dash against [each other]
[In] the wide bazaar, husbands [and their] women that lifted in their storeyed houses
Pretty, sweet smoke, and the smoke from sacrificial fires,
The many, different flower[-like] smoke mingling [together],
A mixed crowd [of] precious lives [= people] who do not know, [despite] measuring
The palace of the Pāṇṭiyaṉ with a a chest of shining ornaments [from] victorious battles,
Appearing in order to come and see(?), you can see at the southern breeze of Maturai has come here,
That is unlike the southern breeze from the Potiyil mountain,
That is united with the straight/perfect tongues of poet-scholars?
It is not very far, his [the Pāṇṭiya king’s] brilliant, abundant, ancient town.
Even if one passes [= travels] [in] a state of solitude, there are no [more] obstructors.’
In the [same] manner as the previous day, the departers departing
On the following [day], in the midde of the night, with the first lady of great penance,
The big temple with the god of difficult wrath, the palace of great fame
[Of] the king [with] a great name, the sound of the intense voice of the Muracam drum
[In] the morning, that is superior among many instruments
Of the excellence of [having many] divisions/classifications,
The sound of Brahmins proclaiming the four Vedas,
The sound of great penitants abounding, having recited [sacred texts],
The Muḻavam drum [with] daily [= fresh] ornaments that swordsmen lifted
Along with the excellence of of the king with victory that does not disappear,
The loud resounding of battle-elephants that were taken from the war,
The loud resounding of strong elephants taken as tribute [from war],
The sound of horses being restles, stationed at bamboo poles/stables,
And the rhythmic song (?) [at] dawn of warriors/minstrels stationed [by] the Kiṇai drum,
As the loud bustle of Kūṭal competed with the sound of the stormy seas,
The great sorrow [of the travellers] leaving;
Everywhere, a string-girdle [of] the curved shore in which
Many flowers opening on the high things [= trees] of Kuravam, Vakuḷam, Kōṅkam, Vēṅkai,
Maravam, Nākam, Tilakam, Marutam, Cēṭalam, Cerunti and Ceṇpakam
Along with Pāṭalam; the creepers of Kuruku, Taḷavan, the rich Mucuṇṭai creeper,
Wild jasmine with expanding flowers, white Kūṭāḷam, Kuṭacam, Vetiram,
The rich Pakaṉṟai creeper, the Piṭavam, and the Mayilai, were fragrant in [their] variance,
Which went around, being closely set, [her] wide, lifted hips,
[Her] young, beautiful breasts that emit rays, that shone beside each other
[Being] a flowering river islet in which white sand was heaped, - many flowers,
[With] a red mouth [made of] petals that the silk-cotton tree had shed,
Having stood [at] the shore, the lady [with] a beautiful smile [of]
Jasmines [= teeth] [that grow at] waterfalls, [with] long eyes
[Like] black carps that move about transversely, leaping [in the water],
Tresses of shining water from which fragrant blossoms do not leave,
The unfailing /banner of the [Pāṇṭiya] clan called Vaiyai, the flower-creeper
That had united with the tongues of poet-scholars, [she] of superior, great conduct
Who fed, having protected, the world, like one who knew
That which sorrow of the lady [Kaṇṇaki], covering [her face]
In a dress of auspicious, fragrant blossoms,
Controlling, being one who hid full, long tears filling [her] eyes,
The lady with a goose-gait and the Lord/husband worshipping [Vaiyai],
Saying, ‘this is not a river of floods; it is a river of flower-floods’,
Over there, not moving to the great ghat, in which boars with horse-faces,
Boats with elephant-faces and boards with lion-faces were driven,
Going in a wooden raft along with the lady of great penance,
Having reached the southern shore [with] fragrant groves,
As they circumambulated to the right Maturai in which the celestials stayed,
Saying, ‘It [Maturai] possesses fitness to a very large degree’,
There, going around a moat that was fitted with a difficult thicket [of vegatation],
The black long waterlily, the waterlily and the lotus,
As though being ones who know without a doubt the singular, great suffering
Of the lady and [her] husband, Being sorrowful, lamenting [and] despairing,
Taking on tears, [along with] bees [with] the nature of music,
Shivering upto their stems; tall banners [on] full fortresses that were lifted up,
Having endured war, as though saying ‘do not come’, changing [their nature thus],
Showing the sign [of danger], [They] having reached a paddy-field grove with birds,
They entered the outskirts, to which [nobody] aside from people who practiced Dharma
At the [royal] seat [of Maturai] that shone [with] agricultural lands flooded [with] water,
Lakes [with] expanding waters, coconut [trees with] bunches of fruit, banana [trees],
Areca palms and arbours [made of] bamboo that were bundled together.
